HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 27, 1925 •

MUSICAL CLUB TO GIVE
TEA DANCE TOMORROW
The second_ of a series of
tea dances sponsored by the
Musical Club will be given in
the Civil Engineering Hall to-morrow, according to an announcement by R. C. Tilghman, President of the Club.
The Blue Jay Orchestra
will furnish the music for the
occasion. "This is the 'Jay's'
first engagement since the
close of their highly successful week at the Maryland
Theatre, so a high quality of
music is assured," said Tilghman.
The dance will begin at 4.30
P.M.

According to a report issued last
week, the Page School of International Relations may assemble a
part of its faculty and start work
next fall.
Marked advances have been
made in the plans for the Page
School. The campaign to raise
$1,000,000, or pledges for that
amount, by the middle of May, is
to be opened soon. The question
as to whether or not more money
must be raised later will be determined when the plans have matured.

Published semi-weekly from October to June by the students of Johns

All letters intended for publication
must be concise, written in ink on
regular letter size paper, on one side
only.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be
printed if request is made that they be
omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to
be taken as an indorsement of its views
by the "News-Letter," which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

THE NEWCOMERS WILL
In spite of the rapidity with which he is being "shoved on
the shelf" by the various political factions concerned with the
administration of Johns Hopkins, the lowly undergraduate still
deserves a few powers. Scorned he may be; but disregarded he
refuses to be.
Chief in a student's rights should be the privilege of being
consulted as to the instructors he wants. Men travel all over
the world in order to be able to study under certain scholars.
Even a Hopkins undergraduate can choose his courses.
At least four new men will be needed next year to take
the places of Doctors Bright, Greene, Vincent, and Thatch. Two
of these vacancies have already been filled tentatively, but as
both of them are heads of departments, the undergraduate is
little concerned. The other positions, however, are those of
undergraduate instructors. No announcements have been made
by our Sphinx-like administrators in reference to possibilities
for these posts. Although the student body is, or should be,
vitally interested in the matter their wishes, and even their
hopes, are not even considered.
Will Hopkins get some really creative men in the English
Department? Will there be "big names" or big men here next
year? Don't ask an undergraduate!

IN THE SPOTLIGHT
While the faculty have been regarding the undergraduate
body as an illegitimate child that despised body has been taking
the spotlight on its own initiative. Most notable in this respect
are the non-athletic activities. The publications have improved.
The 'Musical Club probably did more to attract the notice of
the "outside world" than any other one organization by its
Southern trip, and an unusually long and successful concert
season. When the "Cossack War Song" rang out last Friday
evening at the Mordecai Gist School the Club had completed a
season which had given the Johns Hopkins undergraduate
school the best publicity it had received since the Maryland
football game in 1923.
And tonight, the Barnstormers, after a long siege of rehearsing, will endeavor to continue keeping the undergraduates
"in the spotlight". The production of "A Tailor-Made Man" at
the Lyric tonight and tomorrow night should make the "enemies" of the humble undergrad growl with rage.

The Johns Hopkins Rifle Team
defeated an old rival Saturday,
when it downed the University of
Maryland team 1825-1717. The
match was fired shoulder to shoulder on the Homewood range. The
Hopkins men outshot their opponents in every position except
prone, which was tied. Reiblich
was easily the individual star of
the day, with a score of 10 points
higher than that of Baird, his nearest competitor on the Hopkins
team. The individual scores of the

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 27. 1925
FRESHMEN TO ORGANIZE
TENNIS TEAM
Schedule to Include Leading
"Prep" Schools

A regular tennis is the latest
activity of this year's freshman
.lass. Through the efforts of
Charles H. Wyatt, '28, two
matches have been scheduled, and
six other schools challenged. A
six-man team will represent the
freshman this spring.
While it is still too early to
Practice out of doors, several of
the prospective team members
have entered the indoor tourney
Conducted by "The Evening Sun".
Through an arrangement made by
The Evening Sun" with the Fifth
Regiment authorities, entrants in
the tournament will be able to
Practice at the armory on certain
afternoons during the week.

Framed in the semblance of worn leaves of gold
Your young face looks as wistfully away .
As when you dreamed before the brush one day
At some dim, unremembered time of old.
Forgotten child, your smiling eyes unfold
The awful chill of years. What did you say
That moved the_vanished painter to portray
Your smile so well within those leaves of gold?

Nominations for Editor-inChief and Business Manager
of the 1926 Hullabaloo were
made at a meeting of the Junior Class last Monday. Henry
R. Turnbull, Arthur L. Nelson and Harold Goodwin were
offered as candidates for the
Editor's post, and George
Snoops, Bayard Fonda and J.
Jackson Kidd were nominated
for Business Manager.
The election will take place
on Monday at 12:20, in room
109 M. E. Building.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 27, 1925 •

MUSICAL CLUB TO GIVE
TEA DANCE TOMORROW
The second_ of a series of
tea dances sponsored by the
Musical Club will be given in
the Civil Engineering Hall to-morrow, according to an announcement by R. C. Tilghman, President of the Club.
The Blue Jay Orchestra
will furnish the music for the
occasion. "This is the 'Jay's'
first engagement since the
close of their highly successful week at the Maryland
Theatre, so a high quality of
music is assured," said Tilghman.
The dance will begin at 4.30
P.M.

According to a report issued last
week, the Page School of International Relations may assemble a
part of its faculty and start work
next fall.
Marked advances have been
made in the plans for the Page
School. The campaign to raise
$1,000,000, or pledges for that
amount, by the middle of May, is
to be opened soon. The question
as to whether or not more money
must be raised later will be determined when the plans have matured.

THE NEWCOMERS WILL
In spite of the rapidity with which he is being "shoved on
the shelf" by the various political factions concerned with the
administration of Johns Hopkins, the lowly undergraduate still
deserves a few powers. Scorned he may be; but disregarded he
refuses to be.
Chief in a student's rights should be the privilege of being
consulted as to the instructors he wants. Men travel all over
the world in order to be able to study under certain scholars.
Even a Hopkins undergraduate can choose his courses.
At least four new men will be needed next year to take
the places of Doctors Bright, Greene, Vincent, and Thatch. Two
of these vacancies have already been filled tentatively, but as
both of them are heads of departments, the undergraduate is
little concerned. The other positions, however, are those of
undergraduate instructors. No announcements have been made
by our Sphinx-like administrators in reference to possibilities
for these posts. Although the student body is, or should be,
vitally interested in the matter their wishes, and even their
hopes, are not even considered.
Will Hopkins get some really creative men in the English
Department? Will there be "big names" or big men here next
year? Don't ask an undergraduate!

IN THE SPOTLIGHT
While the faculty have been regarding the undergraduate
body as an illegitimate child that despised body has been taking
the spotlight on its own initiative. Most notable in this respect
are the non-athletic activities. The publications have improved.
The 'Musical Club probably did more to attract the notice of
the "outside world" than any other one organization by its
Southern trip, and an unusually long and successful concert
season. When the "Cossack War Song" rang out last Friday
evening at the Mordecai Gist School the Club had completed a
season which had given the Johns Hopkins undergraduate
school the best publicity it had received since the Maryland
football game in 1923.
And tonight, the Barnstormers, after a long siege of rehearsing, will endeavor to continue keeping the undergraduates
"in the spotlight". The production of "A Tailor-Made Man" at
the Lyric tonight and tomorrow night should make the "enemies" of the humble undergrad growl with rage.

Regiment authorities, entrants in
